awd_titl_txt: International Collaboration in Chemistry:ELECTRONIC STRUCTURE OF BIOLOGICAL METALLO-CLUSTER AND ITS MAGNETIC INTERPLAY WITH THE PROTEIN SURROUNDING IN THERMOPHILE METALLOENZYMES
awd_abstract_narration:
This International Collaboration in Chemistry (ICC) award in the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) program in the Division of Chemistry supports work by Professor Sergei Dikanov from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, in collaboration with Dr. Toshio Iwasaki of Nippon Medical School, Japan, and Dr. Takashi Kumasaka of Japan Synchrotron Radiation Research Institute (JASRI)/SPring-8, to study the influence of the protein environment on the electronic structure of the reduced [2Fe-2S] clusters, in which the ligands to the iron(II) site can be (Cys)2, (His)1(Cys)1, or (His)2.  This project will explore the complete three-dimensional landscape of the unpaired spin density distribution over the cluster and neighboring key amino acid residues in order to identify the residues having the major influence on the electronic structure of the reduced [2Fe-2S] cluster in hyperthermophilic tractable iron-sulfur proteins. To achieve the goal, a complementary set of multifrequency pulsed EPR approaches will be applied to wild-type proteins, using frozen solutions and single-crystals, and to proteins with uniform and site-specific stable isotopic (2H, 15N, 13C, 57Fe) substitution.  The spectroscopic approaches will be combined with ultrahigh-resolution X-ray crystallography, and theoretical calculations.  This project will provide excellent training opportunities to young scientists who will gain invaluable multidisciplinary international research experience via bidirectional visits. This project is jointly supported by the NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS).

All major electron transfer chains incorporate iron-sulfur clusters, and the environment of the cluster is the main determinant of the redox and/or catalytic activity. Their roles in catalysis of energy conversion are of central importance in photosynthesis, respiration, and many ancillary metabolic processes. Our understanding of these determinants is essential to a deeper knowledge how these processes work, and of critical importance in knowing how to optimize such processes, for example in generation of biofuels.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The structure of a metal site critically influences the fine-turning of redox and/or catalytic activities in metalloenzymes, where protein crystallography serves as an excellent technique for determining metal ion stoichiometry, locating metal ions within a protein fold, and identifying amino acid ligands. The electronic structure of the biological redox center and its dependence on the immediate protein environment, which can be best addressed through the combined efforts of spectroscopy and crystallography, are among the keys in the redox chemistry of life: they are major determinants of the redox and/or chemical reactivity of metalloenzymes, and the luck of information thereof translates to uncertainties in corresponding theoretical analyses.      

This interdisciplinary research project is based on a collaboration between the EPR spectroscopists from the US (Dr. Dikanov, UIUC), and the biochemists (Dr. Iwasaki, Nippon Medical School) and protein X-ray crystallographers (Dr. Kumasaka, JASRI/Spring-8) from Japan. The research is focused on four proteins in which the [2Fe-2S] cluster ligands can be (His)n(Cys)4-n  (n=0,1,2). Our approach is to employ X-ray crystallography, pulsed electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), and selective 15N and 13C labeling to elucidate the electronic structure of the reduced cluster in three major types of biological [2Fe-2S] proteins via a characterization of the complete 3D landscape of the unpaired spin density distribution over the cluster ligands and other neighboring key amino acid residues, and correlate this knowledge with the function of the particular Fe-S proteins in ET transfer.  

Biochemical work under this project resulted in a series of Escherichia coli expression host strains for selective 15N and/or 13C labeling of 17 standard amino acids (except for serine, aspartate,  and glutamate) to probe the spin density distribution around the [2Fe-2S](His)n(Cys)4-n (n=0,1,2) clusters. The two-dimensional 15N pulsed EPR (2D ESEEM) spectra of the Pseudomonas putida [2Fe-2S](Cys)4 ferredoxin (FdxB)  have revealed individual hyperfine couplings with ~15 different nitrogens around the cluster. This allows us to visualize the short- and long-range spin density transfer from the reduced [2Fe-2S] cluster in its ground state to the key protein residues having a major influence on the electronic structure of the reduced state. The three  largest 15N couplings are assigned to Thr48>Gln87>Gly43 in this order. Of these, two largest couplings appear to be contributed from the nitrogens involved in N-H...S hydrogen bonding with S(Cys) of the cluster ligands.

Exploiting this approach, we have resolved and assigned most of the non-coordinating (weakly coupled) 15N nuclei from Lys45, HIs44/46, and Cys42/61 contributing to the 2D ESEEM spectra of low-potential archaeal Rieske-type [2Fe-2S](His)2(Cys)2 ferredoxin (ARF). All nitrogens are involved in the N-H...S hydrogen bonding network around the cluster.  The His44/64 and Cys42/61 nitrogen couplings are small, whereas, the largest coupling is solely produced by Lys45. In the high-potential Rieske protein sulredoxin (SDX) nitrogen of Ala45, the residue equivalent to Lys45 in ARF, also possesses the largest coupling. This further indicates that the location of the peptide nitrogen in the polypeptide frame possessing the largest 15N coupling in the reduced [2Fe-2S] cluster systems is primarily defined by the types and pattern of the cluster ligands rather than the extensiveness of the N-H...S hydrogen bond network around the cluster.

We then mapped the spin density distribution onto the cysteine ligands for the three major classes of the reduced [2Fe-2S](His)n(Cys)4-n (n=0,1,2) cluster, using the ARF (n=2), the FdxB (n=0), and Thermus thermophilis mitoNEET homolog containing the cluster with (Hi...

The structure of a metal site critically influences the fine-turning of redox and/or catalytic activities in metalloenzymes, where protein crystallography serves as an excellent technique for determining metal ion stoichiometry, locating metal ions within a protein fold, and identifying amino acid ligands. The research is focused on four proteins in which the [2Fe-2S] cluster ligands can be (His)n(Cys)4-n  (n=0,1,2). The two-dimensional 15N pulsed EPR (2D ESEEM) spectra of the Pseudomonas putida [2Fe-2S](Cys)4 ferredoxin (FdxB)  have revealed individual hyperfine couplings with ~15 different nitrogens around the cluster. This allows us to visualize the short- and long-range spin density transfer from the reduced [2Fe-2S] cluster in its ground state to the key protein residues having a major influence on the electronic structure of the reduced state. The three  largest 15N couplings are assigned to Thr48>Gln87>Gly43 in this order. Of these, two largest couplings appear to be contributed from the nitrogens involved in N-H...S hydrogen bonding with S(Cys) of the cluster ligands.

Exploiting this approach, we have resolved and assigned most of the non-coordinating (weakly coupled) 15N nuclei from Lys45, HIs44/46, and Cys42/61 contributing to the 2D ESEEM spectra of low-potential archaeal Rieske-type [2Fe-2S](His)2(Cys)2 ferredoxin (ARF). All nitrogens are involved in the N-H...S hydrogen bonding network around the cluster.  The His44/64 and Cys42/61 nitrogen couplings are small, whereas, the largest coupling is solely produced by Lys45. In the high-potential Rieske protein sulredoxin (SDX) nitrogen of Ala45, the residue equivalent to Lys45 in ARF, also possesses the largest coupling. This further indicates that the location of the peptide nitrogen in the polypeptide frame possessing the largest 15N coupling in the reduced [2Fe-2S] cluster systems is primarily defined by the types and pattern of the cluster ligands rather than the extensiveness of the N-H...S hydrogen bond network around the cluster.

We then mapped the spin density distribution onto the cysteine ligands for the three major classes of the reduced [2Fe-2S](His)n(Cys)4-n (n=0,1,2) cluster, using the ARF (n=2), the FdxB (n=0), and Thermus thermophilis mitoNEET homolog containing the cluster with (His)1(Cys)3 ligands ( n=1), as model systems.
